loans.name: Genny Del Rocio

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Bellavista de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, por la gran cantidad de arboles de este delicioso fruto que había en aquellos tiempos.

Cada quince días  se reúnen las señoras del Banco  Comunal Bellavista. Aquí conversamos con la señora  Genny M. que es socia  del Banco Comunal desde que se inicio,  hace seis años, ella tiene una relación de unión libre con el señor Ítalo Moreira de la cual han procreado tres hermosas hijas que se encuentran estudiando en la Universidad.

Ella es una ama de casa que junto a su esposo se dedican al comercio. Ellos compran pollos pequeños en Portoviejo,  los mismos que los entregan al por mayor en la ciudad de Machala, La señora  viaja todos los jueves, en la madrugada reciben los pollitos en gavetas los embarcan en el carro y empiezan su recorrido hacia Machala. Venden hasta 65 gavetas por viaje.
También llevan cubetas para huevos que las compran a su paso por Guayaquil, las mismas que las entregan a una avícola de la localidad lo que también les deja otros ingresos extras. Es así que gracias a los créditos que les ha brindado la fundación Espoir han podido obtener capital para su negocio.

Este nuevo crédito lo van a invertir en adquirir más pollos y cubetas, ya que esta temporada es muy buena y necesitan llevar más productos, por que se viene la época de navidad.

Sus aspiraciones son seguir creciendo en su negocio y terminar su casa que aun la tienen en construcción.
texts.en:
The community of Bellavista is located in Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí, which was known for several years as the city of tamarinds because of the large number of trees that produced this delicious fruit a long time ago.

The women of the Bellavista Communal Bank meet every fifteen days. The staff of Fundación ESPOIR had the chance to speak with Sra. Genny M., one of the members who has been part of this Communal Bank since it started six years ago. She is a common law marriage with Sr. Italo Moreira and they have three beautiful daughters who are currently students at the university.

In addition to being a homemaker, Genny works with her husband in their business. She buys young chickens in Portoviejo and then delivers them in bulk to the city of Machala. Genny travels every Thursday. She receives chickens in cases early in the morning and then loads them into her car before starting her trip to Machala. Genny can sell up to 65 cases per trip. She also carries crates of eggs that she buys when passing through Guayaquil. The eggs are delivered to a local poultry farm, which allows her to generate extra income. Thanks to the loans provided by Fundación ESPOIR, she has been able to obtain capital for her business.

This new loan will be used to buy more chickens and crates. This season has been very good, so she needs to carry more products, especially during the holidays. Her goals are to continue growing her business and finish the construction of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens & crates for shipping eggs

loans.name: Tuvshinbat

texts.en: Tuvshinbat E. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife works as a stock keeper in a Narbad Hospital where she receives a salary 160,000 MNT a month. He was a herdsman in the countryside from 1990 to 2002 and then had a firewood business after moving to the central part of the province. Tuvshinbat is a craftsman of wooden products who started his business in 2008 by opening a workshop in his own yard. Since then he has built a stable operation. He also plants vegetables. In the future, he wants to grow his business. In addition, he is also planning to start a rabbit-farming business and to plant fruit trees in his 5-hectare field. He is a very friendly and hard-working person who has a lot of dreams. Tuvshinbat is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase materials and supplies for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials and supplies

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg T. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her husband tends to his one hundred head of livestock and Narantsetseg operates a dress-making business in a rented place where she produces various kinds of traditional clothes. She started her business in her home in 2002 after her family moved to the capital town  in the province. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and have her own workshop. She is a very friendly and kind person who says "I am planning to grow my sewing business and one day I will have my own work place." Narantsetseg is requesting a 520,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a new electric sewing machine for her business which will help her to produce her garments faster and of higher quality.

loans.use: To purchase a new electric sewing machine

loans.name: Doris Normita

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Bellavista de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Bellavista.

Conversamos con la señora Doris, ella es casada hace 21 años  tiene 3 hijos dos mayores, y una linda bebe que es su adoración. Viven en la casa de los suegros, ya que ellos están ancianos y no hay quien cuide de ellos, además por que su esposo hace muchos años sufrió un accidente muy serio  en el carro donde él trabajaba  razón por lo cual no podía conseguir trabajo.

Nos cuenta la señora que la situación era muy difícil no tenían dinero, es así como una amiga la convenció que se dedicara  a la venta de productos de Yanbal (una revista de productos de belleza, perfumes y otros accesorios) ya lleva varios años y dice que le va muy bien.

Ella sale a vender sus productos puerta a puerta por las noches y también por pedidos que le hacen sus clientes, dice que en muchas ocasiones  compra productos cuando hay ofertas, que salen  a mitad de precio y luego los vende a precio normal lo que le deja mejores ganancias.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más productos que estén de promoción.Es socia fundadora del Banco y está muy agradecida con la fundación Espoir por que le ha ayudado mucho  sobre todo en los momentos más difíciles.

Sus metas son tener su casa propia y darles una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The members of the Bellevista Communal Bank meet in the community of Bellevista in Portoviejo, which has been known for many years as the city of “Los Reales Tamarindos” (a stadium where many soccer matches are held).

Upon speaking with Sra. Doris, she says she has been married for 21 years. She has three children, two of whom are adults and the other is a beautiful baby who she adores. Doris and her family live at the home of her in-laws because they are elderly and not able to care for themselves. Several years ago, her husband was in a serious car accident and is not able to work.

Doris says her situation was very difficult because she did not have any money. A friend convinced her to start selling products manufactured by Yanbal (a company that offers beauty products, perfumes, and other accessories through catalogs). She has done this for several years and says that she has done very well.

Doris sells her products door to door in the evenings and also through orders from her customers. She says that she often buys products when they are on sale. Doris purchases them at half price and then sells them at regular price to generate more income.

This new loan will be used to buy more products that are on sale. Doris is a founding member of her Communal Bank and is grateful to Fundación ESPOIR for the support it has provided during all of her difficult moments.

Her goal is to have a house of her own and provide her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase crèmes, perfumes, costume jewelry, and Yanbal cosmetics

loans.name: Carol's Group

texts.en:
Carol G. is from the village of San Antonio. She is 41 years old and the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Carol G.'s Group.

Carol is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns a store selling wood and wood-related products. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Carol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Carol from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Clemensia

texts.en:
Clemensia S. is a married woman who lives in, Brgy.Tagbino, Vallehermoso, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two businesses:  a carinderia or eatery and a Videoke store. Her husband, Benjamin S. Jr., who is 49 years old, is a farmer. They have children who are between five and 20 years old. Clemensia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Clemensia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 16000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8000 PHP, rising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 18000 PHP for more buy supplies for her eatery so she can continue to save up for the education of her children. Clemensia S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more supplies for her eatery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Munhdul

texts.en:
Munhdul M. is 29 years old and lives with his wife in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. The couple live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife helps him run his business. 

In 2008, he started a used clothing retail business. In 2010, he began running a consumer goods and cellphone business in his town. He usually buys his products from Erlian, a border city in China, and sells them at the local market for a higher price.

For the future, the couple is very focused on growing both of their businesses by expanding their product range. Munhdul is a friendly and positive person who says, "Currently, I am planning to expand those businesses. Further, I want to have my own shopping center." Munhdul is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Mongolian Tugrik (MNT) to purchase more cellphones and clothes for use as working capital for his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more cellphones and clothes.

loans.name: Mendsaihan

texts.en:
Mendsaihan M. is 35 years old and lives with his wife and three children in  the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. His oldest daughter attends a local secondary school, his middle son is in kindergarten, and his youngest son a one-year old baby. Their household's standard is normal. His wife, Odgerel, helps in her husband's business. 

In 2004, after moving from the countryside, Mendsaihan and Odgerel bought and started to run a grocery shop with a working capital of 9,500,000 Mongolian Tugrik (MNT). Since then they have built a stable business operation. 

Mendsaihan is a very hard-working person and is very focused on growing his business. He says, "I plan to expand my grocery shop into a big supermarket." He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more grocery products for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal Con Amor Y Fe Hacia el Desarrollo.

Aquí conversamos con la señora Bertha, es casada y tiene tres hijos dos de ellos ya mayores de edad que estudian en la universidad, el menor  todavía está en el colegio, es muy feliz porque que  todos viven aun en su casa.

Se dedica a la  venta de ropa, en especial la de niños ya que a ella le fascina esa ropa y dice que tiene más salida que las otras. Su estrategia de venta es de puerta en puerta. Empezó con muy poco y ahora su negocio ha crecido mucho porque tiene muchos pedidos.

Es así como va a emplear su nuevo crédito para comprar más mercaderías, en especial vestidos de niñas por que tiene varios encargados. Ingreso al Banco Comunal hace 46 ciclos y está muy contenta.

Su meta es darles una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Every 15 days, the members of the Communal Bank “Con Amor Y Fe Hacia el Desarrollo” (Toward Development with Love and Faith) gather together in Los Bajos de Montecristi. This city is known for a great diversity of traditional products such as straw hats that are famous both inside and outside of the country.

Sra. Bertha is married and has three children, two of whom are adults and studying at the university. The youngest is still in high school. Bertha is very happy because they all still live at home.

She sells clothing, especially children’s clothes because she likes these types of garments and says that they are more popular than other types of apparel. Her strategy is to sell door to door. She started with very little and now her business has grown tremendously because she has many orders.

Bertha will use this loan to buy more merchandise, especially girls’ dresses because she has several orders for these items. She has participated in 46 loan cycles with her Communal Bank and is very pleased. Her goal is to provide her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase girls' dresses

loans.name: Rosa Carmelina

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su riqueza cultural, se  reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal Con Amor Y Fe Hacia el Desarrollo.

Desde hace once años la señora Rosa Carmelina es socia del Banco Comunal, es una ama de casa modelo y está casada desde hace 18 años, tiene dos hijos los cuales viven con ella.

Tiene una tienda de abarrotes (consumo en general) a la cual le dedica mucha atención y amor ya que a ella le encanta lo que hace, porque según ella día a día está en contacto con muchas personas de su comunidad. Dice que se levanta muy de mañana junto con su esposo ya que sus clientes son muy madrugadores y ella tiene que brindarles el mejor servicio ya que de ello dependen sus ventas y sus ingresos, que son muy buenos.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en comprar arroz, azúcar aceites y  otros productos de consumo. Sus aspiraciones son gozar de buena salud, ayudar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y continuar muchos años más en la Fundación Espoir que según ella le ha brindado mucho apoyo.
texts.en:
In Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for its rich culture, fifteen members of the Communal Bank “Con Amor Y Fe Hacia el Desarrollo” (Toward Development with Love and Faith) meet every 15 days.

Rosa Carmelina has been a member of this Communal Bank for eleven years. She is a homemaker and has been married for 18 years. Rosa has two children who live with her.

She has a grocery store (general consumer products) that she manages with much attention and love because she enjoys what she does. Rosa says that every day she comes into contact with many people from her community. She and her husband wake up very early in the morning because her customers are early risers. Rosa has to provide them good service because it drives her sales and revenues, which are very good.

This new loan will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, and other consumer products. Her aspirations are to enjoy good health, help her children become professionals, and continue many more years with Fundación ESPOIR which has provided her much support.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, oil, and other consumer products

loans.name: Junita

texts.en:
Junita C. is from the village of Sto.Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 33 years old. Junita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Junita owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as eggs, cooking oil, shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc. in the local community. Junita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Junita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Junita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Junita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Junita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion S. is a 50-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: fishing and fish vending. She lives in Nylon Shell, Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts, by working hard in her businesses.

Concepcion is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Concepcion is now borrowing 13,000 PHP so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Concepcion aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They are indeed "Dungganon" -- a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. To help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines, you can join our team by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria J. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Nylonshell, Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: general store, fishing and videoke businesses. Her husband, Rodolfo, who is 53 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 23 and 30 years old. 

Candelaria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1992 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing  25,000 PHP which she intends to use to pay for raw materials for a new business venture and the videoke machine which she currently leases so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her businesses and improved living conditions. Candelaria is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

Crescencia S. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 71 years old and married. To make a living, Crescencia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Crescencia also raises chickens, and she also makes vinegar out of coconuts. She sells her vinegar at her small sari-sari store.

Crescencia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Crescencia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Crescencia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

texts.en:
Eight people comprise this village bank. Mrs. Peng H., 44, is the village bank president selected by the members who are located in Preak Ta Mem village, Kandal province. Each member of this village loan will use their money for a different purpose.  

Mrs. Peng H. and her husband, Mr. Dang Try, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate peanuts and corn. Her husband also sells ice cream in the local village. He is able to earn a small profit to support his family. In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Peng H. decided to ask for a loan to buy ice cream ingredients to make ice cream. They have four children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other three attend the local school.

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.en:
Abdumanon S. is 35 years old, married and runs his own business. He operates a dealer center for selling mobile Sim-cards and cards to replenish the phone balance. He is also an expert in computer services. Abdumanon provides computer services such as printing, scanning, lamination, etc. He has already been in this business for three years. 

Abdumanon tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work so that he can satisfy his customers' demands and requirements. He is requesting a loan of US$3000 to purchase Sim-cards and to improve his business place. This is Abdumanon's second loan and he thanks everyone for their support and promises not to let them down and to repay the loan on time.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, to epic mountain passes and to a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with six children who are all adults. Her husband is a miner of stones and he contributes his earnings to the family's needs.  Mwanajuma has been operating her water distribution stall for the past three years, selling water in a shop and from home to her neighboring community. Previously she used to sell fried fish to help support her family.

With the Kshs 25,000 loan, Mwanajuma wants to purchase a water tank as her major challenge is inadequate water storage tanks. She hopes to sell both fresh water and piped water in future. Mwanajuma decided to work with Yehu because it is simple to join and there is no harassment. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Michelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general store and for food for her hogs so she can continue to save up for her children's future education and for house renovation. Joelita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred A. is a member of the Rizal Central Branch of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., a microfinance institution partner of Kiva in the Philippines. She is 57 years old and is married with four children. Her husband is a farmer and, because of their family’s meager income, none of their children is pursuing a degree. Their eldest is engaged in buying and selling while the other three work as drivers and laborers.

Mildred dreamed of having a better life and a nice future for her children and that is why, when she entered ASHI, she became committed to the rules and regulations of the institution. She is recognized as one of the most dedicated and active members. She works hard to receive the benefits ASHI provides to its exemplary members. As a result, her life is getting better and she has proven her dignity and her dedication to rise from poverty.

Mildred is applying for a loan of Php 15,000 to fund her business. She is a dealer in soft drinks in her community and supplies many stores. This additional capital will increases her profit and sustain the demands of her customers.

Mildred’s family is glad there are institutions like ASHI and Kiva who are helping families who direly needs financial assistance but don’t have the capacity to provide collateral to serve as a guarantee for the loan. They are hopeful their dreams in life will soon be meet.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: E. Jeanne est née en 1979 à Houngomè au Bénin et est mariée à DEGAN Jespère, un boucher. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Depuis une dizaine d'année, la famille s'est installée à PK11, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Jeanne n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Jeanne  vend des boissons par le système de distribution. Jeanne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis huit ans que Jeanne exerce cette activité. La clientèle de Jeanne s'agrandit de plus en plus, et Jeanne voudrait renforcer plus son activité pour mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle et se faire plus de profits ; raison pour laquelle Jeanne sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé. Son premier crédit a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Jeanne E. was born in 1979 in Houngomé, Benin and is married to Jespère Degan, a butcher. They have five children, all of whom are in school. For about 10 years, the family has lived in PK11, in the Sèmè-Podji commune in Benin. Jeanne never went to school. In order to meet her needs, as well as those of her family, Jeanne sells beverages through the distribution system. Jeanne gets her stock at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Jeanne has been doing this for 8 years. Jeanne's customer base has been growing more and more, and she would like to improve her business so she can meet her customers' demands better and make more money. This is why she is requesting her second loan through ALIDé. Her first loan was repaid in full.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beverages

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios A. is a widow who lives in Mabinuligon, Barangay Sagasa, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Remedios joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, Remedios is borrowing 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save for the future education of her child. Remedios is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Jessie owns and operates a business providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jessie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Ruth

texts.fr: K. Ruth est née en 1971 à Cotonou et est mariée à HOUNSOU Nicolas, un forgeron. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a quatorze ans environs que Ruth s'est installée avec sa famille à PK11, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Ruth subvient ensemble avec son mari aux différents besoins de ses enfants. Ruth a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Ruth vend des boissons et des tissus à Sèmè-Podji, ce qui lui permet de faire face à ses charges. Ruth achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ruth désire élever un peu plus le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. Compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose pour atteindre son objectif, Ruth sollicite pour une deuxième fois, l'appui financier de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Ruth K. was born in Cotonou and is married to Nicolas Hounsou, a blacksmith. The couple have four children all of whom attend school. About 14 years ago Ruth settled with her family at PK11, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Ruth and her husband provide for the various needs of their children together. Ruth left school at secondary level. For the last ten years, she has been selling beverages and fabric at Sèmè-Podji, this allows her to cope with her expenses. Ruth buys her stock at Dantokpa, the Benin international market. She would like to develop her activity and better satisfy her customers' demands . In view of the inadequate means at her disposal for achieving her objective, Ruth is requesting for the second time, the financial support of ALIDé.The first loan was repaid correctly.

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of beverages and fabric

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie A. is from the village of Andarayan South, Solana, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Lanie is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lanie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lanie is just starting this business.

In 2008, Lanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. Lanie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lanie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: M. Toussainte

texts.fr: A. M. Toussainte est née en 1959 à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Toussainte vit depuis sa naissance dans ce quartier. Toussainte est une veuve, et mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Toussainte vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les différentes charges. Pour y parvenir, Toussainte  mène comme activité, la vente de seaux et bassines en plastique, de même que des glacières à son domicile. Toussainte s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Toussainte exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et a dé jà bénéficié de trois prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but de rehausser son activité et d'accroître sa clientèle et donc son chiffre d'affaire, Toussainte sollicite un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Toussainte M. A. was born in 1959 in Lokokoukoumè, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Toussainte has lived in this neighbourhood since her birth. She is a widow and mother of two children, one of whom attends school. Toussainte lives alone with her children and supports the various expenses single-handedly.To manage this, Toussainte runs a business selling buckets, plastic bowls as well as ice boxes at her home. She buys her stock at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Toussainte has been running her business for seven years and has already received three loans all of which have been correctly paid back to ALIDé.With the objectives of developing her activity and increasing her clientele and thus her income, Toussainte requests a fourth loan.

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of buckets and plastic bowls and ice boxes.

loans.name: Tuungane Group

texts.fr: Salama Immaculée est  secrétaire du groupe Tuungane, âgée de 39 ans, mariée, mère de 6 enfants, son mari est  enseignant. Son fils ainé a 17 ans et le cadet a 7 ans et tous étudient. Il y a 5 ans qu’elle exerce son business de vente de divers. Elle a commencé avec ses fonds propre reçu de son mari environ 100$. Elle vend de sucre, Omo, riz, Fanta, etc. Elle expose ses marchandises dans le marché central de Virunga. Ce crédit va lui permettre d'augmenter  son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 10 sacs de Riz, 5 sacs d’Omo, de Fanta, etc. Le grand obstacle est qu’elle vend parfois en crédit et que certains clients ne lui payent pas ou parfois payent avec retard. Elle souhaite acheter une parcelle pour ses enfants et y construire. La cliente Salama Immaculée remercie  Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Tuungane est composé de 16 membres.
texts.en:
Immaculée Salama is the secretary of the Tuungane solidarity group, which has 16 members. She is 39 years old, married, and the mother of six children. Her husband is a teacher. Her eldest son is 17, the youngest 7, and all children attend school. She has been in the retail business for five years, selling miscellaneous items. She started out with her own funds, approximately $100, which her husband gave her. She sells sugar, Omo, rice, Fanta, etc. She has a booth at the central market of Virunga. With this loan, she will increase her sales by purchasing 10 bags of rice, 5 bags of Omo, Fanta, etc. Her biggest challenge is that she occasionally sells on credit, and some customers delay payment, or do not pay at all. She wants to buy a plot of land and build on it, for her children. Immaculée Salama wishes to thank the Hekima MFI for supporting underprivileged people who do not have access to traditional banks.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 bags of rice, 5 bags of Omo, Fanta, etc.

loans.name: Redela

texts.en:
Redela C. is 51 years old and married. She  supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  used clothing and ready-to-wear (RTW) businesses. She lives in Brgy. Tugas, Tanjay City, Negros Oriental. 

Redela has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her used clothing and RTW businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 6400 PHP. 

Redela is now borrowing 19,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Redela aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Neema Group

texts.fr: Masika A. est  trésorière du groupe Neema, âgée de 40 ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants, son mari est cultivateur. Tous ses enfants étudient sauf le cadet qui a encore 2 ans. Juste l’après l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo, qui aurait complètement détruit la ville de Goma en 2002, elle  commença son business avec son fond propre par la vente des  poissons fumés. Son capital initial était de 100$. Plus tard, elle bénéficia du crédit de  Hekima de 50$ pour renforcer son business de commerce vente poissons fumés. Elle expose ses marchandises au long de la rue, point de vente « Deux lampes ». Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir d’approvisionner  son stock  de 15 paniers. Les poissons qu’elle vend viennent de Vitshumbi, la plus  grande pêcherie du lac Edouard  autrement appelé lac Idi-Amin. Le plus grand obstacle c’est la pourriture et le muettement des poissons  suite au manque d’un bon système de conservation et transformation.  Elle souhaiterait  avoir une parcelle et y construire une maison pour sa famille, actuellement elle habite dans un Lodge familial. La cliente Masika A. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Neema est composé de 17 membres.
texts.en:
Masika A. is the treasurer of the Neema group. She is 40 years old, married to a farmer, and the mother of five children. All her children are in school except for the youngest who is only 2 years old. Right after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, which completely destroyed the town of Goma in 2002, she began a commerce selling smoked fish with her own funds. Her starting capital was $100, and later she was granted a $50 loan from Hekima to strengthen her business. She displays her wares along the street, at the “Two Lamps” point of sale. This new loan will enable her to resupply her stock of 15 baskets. The fish she sells come from Vitshumbi, the largest fishery of Lake Edward, also known as Lake Idi-Amin. Her biggest problem is the decaying and flaking of fish due to a lack of adequate conservation and processing techniques. She would like to own a plot of land and build a home for her family, as she now lives in a family lodge. Masika A. – a client of Hekima - thanks the organisation for its actions in favor of empoverished citizens who do not have access to classic banking services. It should be noted that the Neema group consists of 17 members.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 15 baskets of fish

Sènoumè vend divers produits (conserves de tomate et de sardines, pâtes alimentaires, lait, savons, couscous, huile d'arachide, etc.) à son domicile ; ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille. texts.en:
Sènoumè Zounhoeva was born in 1975 in Lokokoukoumè in the Sèmè-Podji borough, and is married to Firmin Chaganou, an automobile mechanic. She is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. She has lived in Lokokoukoumè since her childhood. Sènoumè retails a variety of products from her home (canned tomatoes and sardines, pasta, milk, soap, cuscus, peanut oil, etc.). This enables her to meet her needs and those of her family. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Sènoumè wants to increase her working capital and her turnover, which is why she is requesting financial support from ALIDé. She had previously been granted two loans from ALIDé, both of which were duly repaid.

loans.name: Jene

texts.en:
Jene B. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 39 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jene is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Agnès

texts.fr: Née en 1982 à Dangbo dans le département de l'Ouémé, D. Agnès est mariée à LAÏFA Norbert, un chauffeur. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. La famille s'est installée depuis trois ans à PK10, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins des enfants. Agnès n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Agnès prépare et vend de l'"akassa" (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs) accompagné de poissons frits à son domicile. Agnès s'approvisionne en maïs et poissons frais à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Agnès exerce cette activité depuis neuf ans et a déjà obtenu deux prêts qui ont été bien remboursés. Dans le but d'augmenter le volume de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Agnès sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1982 in Dangbo in the Ouémé department, Agnès D. is married to Norbert Laïfa, a driver. They have three children under their care, of whom two are their own. All the children attend (or have attended) school. Three years ago the family settled in PK10, in the Sèmè-Podji district of Benin. The couple shares responsibility for handling the children’s various needs. Agnès has never been to school. To meet her needs she prepares and sells “akassa” (a local food preparation based on cornstarch) served with fried fish, from her home. Agnès gets her supplies of corn and fresh fish from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Agnès has been running her business for the past nine years and has already been granted two loans that were fully reimbursed. Wishing to increase her turnover and improve customer satisfaction, she is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, fish, peanut oil and bundles of wood.

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda F. is from the village of San Juan. She is 35 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a weaving business, making and selling sedge mats and mattresses to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $62 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make woven products. Emelda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to expand her product offerings. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

loans.name: Twibumbebahinzi Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 49 years old, married with 5 children who are 5, 7, 8, 12, and 15 years old.  Jacqueline is the leader of a group called 'Twibumbebahinzi'.  Jacqueline and her team are widely known in the business of selling agricultural products.  They have been in this business for a long time and their business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Jacqueline and her team need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  Once given this loan, they will expand the businesses through purchasing different agricultural products.  With these additional agricultural products for sale, they really hope that their sales as well as profits will increase to an extent that they will be able to keep reinvesting in their businesses for a better financial stability.

loans.use: the purchase of different agricultural products

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora T. is from the village of Larion Bajo, Tuguegarao City. She is 52 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. She makes a living as a blacksmith, manufacturing simple knives to sell in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately $110 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Teodora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Teodora is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes M. is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut paste and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried and fresh fish.  Agnes is 31 years old and is married to a driver. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock dried and fresh fish

loans.name: C9453 Abunzubumwe Group

texts.en:
Joseline is 28 years old, married and raising 3 children who are 2, 6, and 8 years.  Joseline is the leader of a group called Abunzubumwe and this group is widely known in the business of selling agricultural products.  They have been in this business for a long time and the business hours are from 8 am until 3 pm every day.

Joseline and her team need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Joseline and her team will expand their businesses through purchasing a large quantity of additional agricultural products which in turn will permit their sales as well as well as profits to rise.  If successful, there is a hope that each member's living standard will improve and in addition to that, they will start saving for a better future.

loans.use: buying various agricultural products for resale

loans.use: buy construction materials for an addition to his house

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito S. Jr. is from the village of San Juan. He is 36 years old. Juanito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Juanito owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling breads, cakes, and cookies to the local community. Juanito has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juanito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Juanito is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in his business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Juanito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Flordeliza

Flordeliza N. is from the village of San Juan. She is 40 years old. Flordeliza is married and has four children. To make a living, Flordeliza owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Flordeliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flordeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Flordeliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mwamini

texts.en:
Mwamini is 44 years old, married with four children.  Mwamini is widely known in the business of selling different styles of clothes.  She has been in this business for about 13 years and her business hours are from 7 am until 7 pm every day.

Mwamini needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Mwamini will expand her business through purchasing more styles of clothes which will mainly include styles for young people because these styles are highly demanded.  With this additional clothing for sale, Mwamini will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting for a better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: buying different of clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy a new sewing machine and hire an apprentice

loans.name: Baasanjav

texts.en:
Baasanjav B. lives with his wife and two children in Hovd, a western province of Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, known locally as a "ger". His son currently attends a local secondary school, and his daughter is set to begin study at a university. 

Baasanjav currently operates a taxi service as well as a firewood trading business in his town. He started his firewood selling business in 2003, and after one year of strong growth, he used his earnings to purchase the car that he uses for his taxi service. Today, he operates his taxi service while his wife sells firewood. 

They also supplement their income by selling dairy products in summer time. Their firewood business has become profitable because they sell the firewood near ger districts where most people use wood to heat their homes. Baasanjav is a hardworking man and says, "I think my wife and I can make our business even better." 

 He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase firewood from wholesalers.

loans.use: To purchase firewood

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana B. is from the village of Cabisera II. She is 37 years old. Feliciana is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Feliciana owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Feliciana has been engaged in her business for more than 14 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Feliciana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliciana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Feliciana from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: A. Pascaline est née en 1973 à Agonrin-Houegbo, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Mariée à HOUNKPEGAN Michel, un tailleur, Pascaline est mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. La famille s'est installée à PK10, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis une dizaine d'année. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pascaline n'a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris la couture. C'est cette activité que Pascaline exerce depuis sept ans et qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Parallèlement à cette activité, Pascaline vend divers produits de mercerie dans son atelier à PK10. Pascaline achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement deux crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de rehausser son chiffre d'affaire, Pascaline sollicite un troisième concours financier.
texts.en:
A. Pascaline was born in 1973 in Agonrin-Houegbo, in Atlantique county, Benin. She is married to HOUNKPEGAN Michel, a tailor, and is the mother of three children, of whom some are in school. The family settled in PK10, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, about ten years ago. The couple jointly ensure that their different family expenses are covered. Pascaline did not go to school but learned how to sew. This has been her work for seven year. It enables her to support herself and her children. Concurrently, Pascaline sells various sewing supplies in her workshop in PK10. She purchases her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a previous client of ALIDé having had two loans in the past that she repaid. With the goal of bolstering her business and increasing her sales, Pascaline is requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various sewing supplies

loans.name: Elsa  Marlyse

texts.fr:
femme de 35  ans celibataire et mère de 3 enfants dont l'age varie de 4 mois a 17 ans. Après son  baccalaureat n'ayant plus de soutien financier et ayant 3personnes en charge, elle se lança dans le commerce de vente de tissus en 2005 avec un capital de 80000frs.
Avec ce prêt elle veut agrandir son activité en achetant des tissus comme borsalino, du lin,de la soie des tissus de céremonies et autres tissus de premièrs qualites.
sa strategie est de vendre au prix hors concurrence et toujours avoir une bonne marchandise, épargner toutes les semaines.
elle aimerait être grossiste dans les jours futurs, elle veut que son commerce prospère, elle aimerait que sa famille vive dans des meilleurs conditions en ameliorant leurs conditions de vies et qu'elle prospère.
son entourage la felicite pour ses initiatives  et pour son esprit de creativité.
texts.en:
This is a 35-year-old woman who is unmarried and the mother of three children, who range in age from 4 months to 17 years. After graduating from high school and without any more financial support, plus three people in her care, she got started in a business selling cloth. This was in 2005 with 80,000 francs in capital. With this loan, she wants to expand her business by buying some fabrics, such as felt, linen, silk, ceremonial cloth, and other top quality fabrics. Her strategy is to sell at unrivaled prices, to offer good merchandise at all times, and to save money every week. She would like to be a wholesaler in the days to come. She wants her commerce to prosper. She would like her family to live under the best conditions and to prosper. Her friends and family compliment her on her initiative and creative spirit.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying linen, poplin, silk, felt, and ceremonial cloth

loans.name: Batdemberel

texts.en:
Batdemberel G., 38, lives with her husband and three children in Uvurhangai, one of Mongolia's aimag centers, or provinces. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, called a ger, on a small plot of land that they own. 

Her husband works in a local market as a guard. Her older daughter attends a university while her son is a monk at a monastery.

 In 2003, after moving from the countryside, Batdemberel completed training that specialized in tailoring and sewing clothes. After this training, she started a clothes-making business in a rented room at the Noyon Hairhan NGO building. She makes and sells a variety of clothing items, but specializes in traditional Mongolian clothes and children's clothes. 

Her monthly sales are approximately 600,000-700,000 MNT. She receives lots of orders during Tsagaan Sar, the lunar new year celebration, and Naadam, the summer sporting festival. She is a very hardworking and diligent person who hopes to keep growing her business and providing her customers with quality products. Batdemberel is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to expand her tailoring business.

loans.use: To expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi is married with a housewife and four children. One child is married and two still attend school. He has been operating his poultry business for the last seven years, and sells in a shop and at the market to restaurant operators. Previously, he was a carpenter.

With the Kshs 20,000, he wants to purchase chickens to increase his stock. Hamisi faces the major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to be a wholesale marketer in future. 

He is working with Yehu after learning its procedures and that it is community-based. He owns a home with electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and medicine.

loans.use: To purchase chickens to increase stock.

loans.name: Joseph Nganga

texts.en:
Joseph Nganga K. is a 44-year-old gentleman who is married to one wife named Winne Muthoni. He is a photographer who takes photos of people and reproduces them at a fee within Nairobi city centre. He also takes photos on request and at a fee for weddings, birthdays and ceremonial parties as well. He has been in the photo business for 13 years and he says that he makes a profit of about Kshs 90,000 per month. His other source of income is his wife’s farming business.

Joseph joined KADET after being introduced by his friend and he is currently accessing his fourth loan. He plans to use this loan to purchase another digital camera to take better quality photos. 

His future aspirations are to operate a photography training institute in the city centre and also be able to maximize his profits.

loans.use: purchasing another digital camera

loans.name: Dorjderem

texts.en:
Dorjderem D. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and three-year-old son in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They have been living at their current address for more than 20 years. His son currently attends a local kindergarten, and his wife, Delgermaa, runs a small business. 

Over the years, Dorjderem has had difficulty finding work and his family lives in poverty. He ran a car repair center with his friends back in 2003, but it is not open anymore. Dorjderem started driving a taxi using his own car in 2006. Since then, he has gained much experience and had modest success. He has a strong moral character and is a very hardworking person. 

Dorjderem hopes to one day establish his own car repair center. He is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to purchase tools and equipment to prepare his car for the cold winter months.

loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment to prepare his taxi for winter

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a married woman with four girls and one boy; four of the children attend school while one is still too young for school. Her husband is a fisherman and he contributes to supporting the family. She has been selling food for over three years to her neighbours and passersby in a shop. With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, rice, beans and charcoal for sale. She has no other source of income.

Zena faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.She hopes to open a restaurant in future. She decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans. She owns a home with no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, rice, beans, and charcoal for resale

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline J. is currently in the business of selling locally brewed alcohol and beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Jackline is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is an electrician . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real bar.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Oyungerel D. is 45 years old and lives as a single mother with her three children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. The family have been living at their current home address since 1998. Her oldest daughter lives and works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, while her middle daughter attends a university and her youngest daughter stays at home. 

She graduated from the technology institute in 1983 and then she worked as a seamstress until 1995. She started her wooden products trading business in 2000 after selling three billiard tables made by her brother-in-law. She usually produces  wooden items such as chairs and bowls and sells them at a local market. She operates this wooden products making business in her town with help of her brother-in-law.

 In the future, to further support her family, she hopes to grow her business by increasing the quantity and quality of products she produces. She is a diligent and hardworking person and says "I try my best to raise my children very well, but it is little bit difficult since I am a single mother with three children." She also wishes to buy a car which would contribute greatly to her business operations. 

Oyungerel is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase new tools and equipment in order to expand her wood products production.

loans.use: To purchase new tools and equipment

loans.name: Marriam

texts.en: Marriam E. is currently in the business of selling fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and yams to sell.  Mariam is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a book shop.

loans.use: stock Irish potatoes and yams to sell

loans.name: Kamelle

texts.en: Kamelle M. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, rice, beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fish, tomatoes  and pulses (lentils) to sell.  Kamelle is 47 years old and is widowed.   She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock fish, tomatoes  and pulses (lentils) to sell

loans.name: Pagamsuren

texts.en:
Pagamsuren D. lives with her husband and two sons in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic dwelling, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband works in a local market as a guard and they have been living in their current home, which belongs to her mother-in-law, since 1999. She started her grocery trading business at a rented space in Mon-Mandal, a local market in her town.

 Before beginning her business, she worked in a food store as a salesperson.  Her business operation has expanded by increasing the variety of products at her grocery shop. Her business has grown quickly over the years and her total turnover reaches 1,520,000 MNT today. Her average monthly sales profit is 120,000 MNT and she receives 36,3000 MNT as salary per month.

 In the future, she plans to expand her business by continuing to increase the number and variety of products she sells. She is a very  modest and optimistic businesswoman. Pagamsuren is requesting a 1, 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes to sell in her store.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine J.  is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs such as cooked rice, beef, etc in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize flour, rice and beans to be cooked and sold in the restaurant.  Christine is 39 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize flour, rice and beans to be cooked and sold in the restaurant

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en:
Uranchimeg G. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her older daughter attends a university while her younger daughter goes to a local secondary school. Her husband is a craftsman who makes various kinds of wood products.

 Uranchimeg operates a firewood-selling business with the help of her husband at a local market in her town. She started her business as a local coal and firewood market in 2003. She purchases her firewood from the same local market where she resells it so there are no transportation costs. She also began another business in May of this year where she sells used clothing. Her firewood sales increase during winter time.

 She is a friendly and hardworking person who says "I hope to one day save up enough money to expand my used clothing business." Uranchimeg is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and coal at wholesale prices to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and coal

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty N. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions, bread and fried fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes, more fish and cooking oil to sell.  

Betty is 23 years old and married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock Irish potatoes, more fish and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Affa

texts.en:
Affa J. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal and firewood at her home. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour and beans to sell.  

Affa is 31 years old and married to a peasant. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Alexandrine

texts.fr: Née en 1981 à Agbalilamè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Alexandrine s'est mariée à ASSALIA Aloussessi, un commerçant. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés. Alexandrine réside à Lokokoukoumè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji depuis son enfance. Alexandrine vend des produits de beauté et des mèches dans son domicile. Alexandrine achete ses produits de beauté à Dantokpa, marché international du BENIN et les mèches au NIGERIA le pays voisin. Alexandrine veut augmenter son capital et élever le niveau de son activité ; raison pour laquelle Alexandrine sollicite auprès de ALIDé un second prêt. Alexandrine a bien remboursé son premier crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1981 in Agbalilamè in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. A. Alexandrine was married to Mr. ASSALIA Aloussessi, a merchant. The couple have three children who are all in school. Alexandrine has been living in Lokokoukoumè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, since her childhood. She sells beauty products and hair extensions out of her home. She purchases the beauty products at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and the hair extensions from Nigeria, a neighboring country. Alexandrine wants to increase her capital and to elevate her level of business. For these reasons, she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé. She has indeed repaid her first loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying beauty products and hair extensions

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a rented house in Tuv province in central Mongolia. Her older son attends a local secondary school.  Her youngest daughter is at home. 

Her husband has a small truck and he carries people's loads, using his truck to support his family. From 1999 to 2006, the family lived in the countryside as a nomadic lifestyle. Since 2006, after moving from the countryside to the central city of Tuv province, they brought their milking cows to sell milk and yogurts. She has many permanent customers. 

She is a very generous and open-minded person. She says, "I plan to increase the number of cows and establish a cow farming." She is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) loan to purchase two cows at 1,500,000 MNT as well as 1,000,000 MNT for fodder for her livestock.

loans.use: To purchase two cows and fodder for her livestock

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren D. lives with his wife and nineteen-year old son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family have lived together in their own yards since 2000. His son, Chimegserchin, has recently graduated a secondary school and will attend a university this year. 

He started up his business by selling a variety of meats to his customers at a rented stall in the local market, in 2002. Also he began an extra business to operate a taxi service within his town. He is a very communicative and open minded person who says " I try my best to provide my child with a higher education." Purevsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan to use for several purposes such as: pay his child's tuition fees, pay accomodation fees, and purchase a variety of meats to sell.

loans.use: To pay child's tuition fees

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A.  is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese bread such as legemat, gelabia, and tamia, and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour and cooking oil to sell.  Nana is 32 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: buying more baking flour and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine B. lives in the village of Gandzaqar near the town of Ijevan. She is married and has two children. Her son lives in Russia, her daughter lives with her parents. Karine works in the National Statistic Service Ijevan Agency. 

For the past ten years, she has engaged in bee-keeping on the side. Her husband and father-in-law help Karine with this hard work. Karine had a bee-allergy and initially kept the animals at a great risk for her health, but during the years of her work she has gained immunity. Karine developed her business on her own land and sells all her honey very quickly, because she has regular customers. 

With the good income from bee-keeping Karine solves the most significant part of her family’s financial problems. She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian drams to buy wax papers, frames, boxes and medicinal agents for her bee families. 

This is Karine's fourth loan from Nor Horizon and second loan from Kiva; and Karine has never been delinquent with her repayments.

loans.use: to buy wax papers, frames, boxes and medicinal agents for beekeeping

loans.name: Nansalmaa

texts.en:
Nansalmaa S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All three of her daughters attend a local secondary school. 

Her husband operates a transportation business, using his small track, to support the family. Nansalmaa operates a firewood selling business at a local market in her town. She started her business at a local coal and firewood market in 2005. She purchases her firewood and coal once a month. Sometimes, she rents a truck to transport her firewood in order to sell it. Her business covers most of her family's expenses. She currently rents a stall at a local market to sell her products. 

In the future, she is planning to expand her firewood trading business by renting more stalls at that market. She is a friendly and hard-working person who says "I plan to rent more stalls at a local market in order to increase my sales." Nansalmaa is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan to purchase more wood and coal at wholesale prices when the price of coal is cheap.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and coal

loans.name: Tsogtgerel

texts.en:
Tsogtgerel L. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His two daughters both go to the local secondary school. 

Tsogtgerel operates a wooden products trading business at the regional market in his province. He started this business in 1997 and has become very experienced.
